Award.AbstractNarration: This NSF funded research project is in topology, a central field in modern mathematics. The main goal is to use ideas from theoretical particle physics (gauge theory)to develop new tools for studying three-dimensional geometric shapes. The principal investigator also plans to apply these tools to study the problem of which high dimensional shapes can be triangulated, that is, decomposed into simple pieces (similar to a decomposition of a surface into triangles). Triangulations have applications beyond pure mathematics, for example in computer graphics. The project also aims to support graduate education and to disseminate mathematical ideas to the general public.<br/><br/>In more technical terms, the project concerns Floer theories associated to three-manifolds, and their topological applications. In particular, the principal investigator will investigate Seiberg-Witten Floer stable homotopy types, the associated Pin(2)-equivariant Seiberg-Witten Floer homology, and involutive Heegaard Floer homology. These theories can be used to get information about the homology cobordism group in three dimensions. In turn, homology cobordism gives insight into the classification of triangulations for manifolds of dimension at least five. The principal investigator also proposes to understand the behavior of Heegaard Floer homology for coverings of 3-manifolds, and to develop 3-manifold invariants from the moduli spaces of SL(2,C) flat connections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project concerns Floer theories, a set of tools used to study objects in low dimensional topology. Floer theories are algebraic structures associated to three-dimensional shapes, or to knots inside these three-dimensional shapes. The PI and his collaborators constructed new Floer theories using ideas from theoretical physics. These new theories are connected to a different algebraic invariant of knots, Khovanov homology, which physicists conjectured that it can be expressed as a Floer theory as well. Khovanov homology was originally defined only for knots in ordinary three-dimensional space, but there are now various proposals about how to extend it to knots inside arbitrary three-dimensional shapes. The PI and his collaborators investigated some of these extensions, and made some constructions from physics mathematically rigorous. They also studied the properties of Khovanov homology with respect to surfaces in four-dimensional space. 

The PI has disseminated this work through talks at 16 conferences, 5 department colloquia, and 11 area seminars. The PI has written one survey article based on his talk at the International Congress of Mathematicians in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. He also gave a lecture for high school students at the International Mathematical Olympiad in Cluj-Napoca, Romania.

Part of the grant was used to support the research of three graduate students: S. Michael Miller, David Boozer, and Ikshu Neithalath. Their PhD theses dealt with aspects of Floer homology and Khovanov homology. They have all moved on to postdoctoral positions in academia.

 


Last Modified: 07/09/2021
Modified by: Ciprian Manolescu
